instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
hello,

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on after fall

5v was drawing 265 amps. CB408 was showing short circuit when I checked. I disassembled the CB408. No more short circuits. but keweisi opens and closes. it shows 5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
Probably damaged USB-C connector.
Did you test the board out of shell, using another connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
I meant replacing (supposed) damaged connector.

Check voltage and diode mode to ground readings on LDOs of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
Voltages come and go as the device turns off and on.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3,3 volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> =1,8 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1,8 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = No voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message: No shorts except CB408. no field with low ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
only 1 entry does not turn off. Restarts on other 3 entries

[URL unfurl="true"]https://disk.yandex.com.tr/i/y0sNFS7Pgb2ePg[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
You must get same behavior on all USB-C ports.

"diode mode to ground readings on LDOs of [B][U]all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips[/U][/B]."
You don't need power for that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
I said there is no short circuit
CB408 was shorted. So could the UB400 be faulty?

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.486
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.459
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.492
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> =0.509

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> =0.509
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> =0.483
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> =0.464
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.492

ub300
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> =0.509
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> =0.502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> =0.465
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.492

ub400
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> =0.509
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> =0.492
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0.459
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.483

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
"only 1 entry does not turn off"
Is that UB400 port?

Check which port gets 1V1 LDO.
Remember, this voltage must appear only on the powered port.

threads.message:

threads.message:
ub300 won't turn off either. and it outputs a constant 1.1 volts.
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>

others show 1.1 volts. but voltage comes and goes as it turns on and off

only ub300 does not turn off. and it outputs a constant 1.1 volts.
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>

others show 1.1 volts. but voltage comes and goes as it turns on and off

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
You may have a problem on that port (UB400).
May be caused by other components, related with the USB-C connector, not UB400 itself.

Board tries to start with both charger and battery connected?

You can check diode mode on all USB-C connector pins, or use some fast tester (S-UEM2).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message: When I check the cb309 in diode mode on another motherboard, it shows 0.502, but I can't get any value in the same part on this motherboard. Do I need to replace the UB300?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V
threads.message:
You should get same value as CB409 and other caps connected to SS pin of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
OL reading means broken trace/solder.
